4 degrees C turns out to be the temperature at which liquid water has the highest density. If you heat it or cool it, it will expand. The expansion of water when you cool it to lower temperatures is unusual, since most liquids contract when they're cooled.

An interesting consequence of this peculiar feature of water is that the temperature of water at the bottom of a lake in the winter is almost always 4 degrees C, since the densest water will settle to the bottom -- if it gets any colder or warmer, it will rise. Ice floats on top of lakes, preventing evaporation (and convection in the frozen layer), and lakes stay liquid underneath, allowing fish and other life to survive.

Its an ANTI BUBBLE  ( look it up)  An antibubble in liquid is a thin film of air surrounding liquid.Antibubbles are formed when liquid drops or flows turbulently into the same or another liquid. They can either skim across the surface of a liquid such as water, in which case they are also called water globules, or they can be completely submerged into the liquid to which they are directed.

This should be actually pretty simple. How often do surfaces of a liquid ever end up approaching one another in the presence of gravity face to face? Most liquids with a decent surface tension will keep the liquid in a shape that stays in conformity to its container. However with a bubble of liquid, the surface is not having the change to penetrate that surface tension. OH(<del>) particles end up all around the outside and form a shield that doesn't like the OH(</del>) particles on the other surface. So a blob of something micro sized finally swings around and stitches them together. Then surface tension takes over and reshapes them into one. It's definitely a special geometry mixed with ionic bonding doing the deed here.

Speculation:

it does have to do with surface tension, not thermodynamics. Electrostatic forces have a small role in this effect as well. The water droplet has surface tension, and the water surface it is touching also has a surface tension. Once the electrostatic charge between the two has achieved equilibrium, the two surfaces will join at a tiny point, then like a bubble.. they pop together and merge. Some of the droplets will penetrate the surface, and for a split second, will remain independent of the larger body of water, until the electrostatic force is no longer sufficient to assist maintaining the surface tension of the droplet. This is the main source of the reason for water being cloudy with air for a short time after filling a glass with water.

Of course.. this is all just combining what I know of normal physics and trying to apply it to the effect in question... there are no studies that i know of that address this. The closest I can think of is sonoluminescence, an effect observed with boat and submarine propellers, and is believed to be the culprit of pitting on corrosion resistant props.

Maybe this has already been said, but as a droplet falls through the air, not all of the water sticks together. Small droplets fall off the main drop, and because they are smaller, the air friction has more of an impact on them, causing the droplets to heat up a tiny amount more. Hot water on cold water will naturally drift higher. So the droplets stick together with itself because of cohesion, as does the pond, but because of the different speeds of the atoms in the different temperatures, the pond and the droplets repel each other for a short amount of time.
When falling onto another liquid layer, water droplets typically bounce then coalesce. If the surface is vibrating, however, the droplets will continue bouncing.

The surface tension of extremely pure water is more than that of an impure one.As you yourself happen to mention that the temperature is "near" freezing.The water droplets falling on the water surface are at about 0 degree Celsius because of latent heat.But the density of the the surface water "MIGHT PROBABLY" be more than the falling water as it's temperature "might" be closer to 4 degree Celsius 'cause of the infrared radiation of the sun during the day. If this should be correct, we know that the density of water is highest at 4 degree Celsius and so the surface tension should be maximum. + the force of cohesion for water is less than the force of adhesion, which should "probably" result in little droplet formation on the surface.

Is it possible that these water droplets are small enough, and the air temperature is cold enough (and whatever other zany conditions may apply) that the droplet's outer few molecules of water freeze, creating enough of an "ice bubble" that the droplet skates on top due to differences in surface tension but then is thawed by the temperature of the larger body of water? That was my first thought, but I like your surfactant idea better. :-)

A surfactant is a compound that greatly reduces the surface tension of a liquid, for example detergents and emulsifiers. That could be possible if there is lime stone (CaCo3) present in the rock. However this wouldn't be the cause because lowering the surface tension would cause the water droplet to break. What is happening is called the coalescence cascade which happens when there is a very thin layer of air underneath the water droplet, which allows it to sit temporarily above the surface.

It has something to do with the molecular bonding of the water molecules at different temperatures.  The water temperature appears to be right above freezing.  In this case, when water hits the ground, the h20 molecules momentarily bonds closer together.  The impact briefly changes the state of matter, which is the motion of the particles and the distance between them.  That's why you see the bubbles right after it hits the ground.

I think it has something to do with the density of water that is in a frozen state. Those water droplets that rest atop the others are in a pseudofrozen state, due to their contact with cold air, and wind from there fall. Therefore they act almost like solid water. Solid water is less dense than liquid water (the reason ice cubes float in a drink), therefore the droplets act as tiny ice cubes that float upon the denser surface. Im just a physics student, but thats the most logical answer.

@mytubechannell It is quite rare that I have a Youtube comment not only agreed upon but elaborated upon.  Thank you, sir.

Incidentally, if one wishes to investigate this phenomenon of surface droplet skittering further, the relevant term used in the literature is water coalescence; and it has been found recently that it proceeds in a self-similar finite cascade of ever smaller mergings called a coalescence cascade. The seminal AIP physics of fluids paper being "The coalescence cascade of a drop" by Thoroddsen and Takehara from 2000.

These are most definitely not antibubbles. Antibubbles are a very specific phenomenon whereby a very thin layer of air encloses a droplet of water whilst fully submerged underwater. These are just water droplets skittering on the surface due to surface tension as "kowality" correctly notes below. Search for "antibubbles" on YT to see the difference.

@kowalityjesus Water is most dense at  4°C. When the droplets fall off the icicle and hit the water of similar temperature and density, this creates a disturbance in the surface of the pool. The droplets which break off  are very dense and cool this I think extends the period of time before they break surface tension.  Surface tension temperature and density are crucial here. See Pollack and Schauberger.

I believe that this is an effect of surface tension, the same thing that allows water striders to move across the surface.  I assume that when the water hits the ground and bounces up in drops, some of the drops form stable spheres, whose surface tension temporarily opposes that of the water on the ground. The bond is not covalent, but related to polarity, a 'hydrogen bond' where the unique shape of water molecule causes a self-affinity at the surface.
